GroundFact

public GroundFact(int relationName,
                  int... cols)
Construct a fact of relation relationName with columns cols of object constants.

Parameters:
relationName - The name of the relation.
cols - The columns of this fact, all object constants.

GroundFact

public GroundFact(SymbolTable symTab,
                  java.lang.String relName,
                  java.lang.String... cols)
Construct a fact of relation relName with columns cols. Takes strings as arguments, and uses symbol table symTab to convert them to integer form. All columns must be object constants.

Parameters:
symTab - The symbol table for converting strings to token numbers.
relName - The name of the relation, to be converted using symtab.
cols - The columns, to be converted using symtab, all representing object constants.

GroundFact

public GroundFact(GdlAtom atom)
Construct a fact of arity zero from atom. The atom's token is taken to be the relation name, and the fact has zero columns.

Parameters:
atom - The atom to build the fact from.
Method Detail

clone

public GroundFact clone(int newRelName)
Clone this ground fact, but with a new relation name. Keeps all columns intact.

Parameters:
newRelName - The new name for the ground fact relation.
Returns:
The cloned fact with the different name.

canMapVariables

public boolean canMapVariables(Expression other)
Description copied from class: Expression
Can this expression be mapped to the other expression? An expression can be mapped to another expression if and only if there is a unifier from the one to the other that only makes variable assignments.

Note that this relationship is not symmetric: one expression can be mapped to another expression, despite that second relation not mapping to the first.

Specified by:
canMapVariables in class Expression
Parameters:
other - The expression with which to test mapping.
Returns:
True if this can be mapped to other.

fromList

public static GroundFact fromList(GdlList list)
Construct a fact from a GdlList. Note that the list must be a list of atoms, in other words, there cannot be any nested lists. The fact is constructed by taking the first element of the list as the fact's relation name, and every subsequent element as a column.

Parameters:
list - The list to build the fact from.
Returns:
A ground fact representing the data from the list.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalAccessException - when the passed list is not a list of atoms.
See Also:
GdlList

                          SymbolTable symtab)
Specified by:
printToStream in class Expression

compareTo

public int compareTo(GroundFact f)
Compare this fact to fact f. Facts are compared first according to their relation name, second according to the number of columns and finally according to the tokens in the columns.

Specified by:
compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<GroundFact>
Parameters:
f - The fact to compare against.
Returns:
-1 if this < f
0 if this == f
1 if this > f

Specified by:
uniquefy in class Fact

unify

public Substitution unify(Fact f)
Description copied from class: Fact
Attempt to unify this fact with fact. If the unification succeeds, return the substitution used -- but does not actually change the facts. If the unification fails, return null.

Note that before attempting to unify with fact, you probably want to make sure that the facts have unique variable names.

Overrides:
unify in class Fact
Parameters:
f - The fact to unify with.
Returns:
The substitution used to unify these, or null.
